The Expert Beginner

A few months ago I read great article written byÂ Erik DietrichÂ -Â How Developers Stop Learning: Rise of the Expert Beginner. After publishing this article, and receiving a lot of positive feedback,Â Erik has written multiple follow up articles.Â He also has writtenÂ a book, which I decided to buy and read: The Expert Beginner ($5 for Kindle Edition!).

This book is a very interesting case study, in which Erik analyzes developer's growth, and how some people get comfortable with their current knowledge, stop learning, and are not willing to step out of their comfort zone. Erik calls this stage: "Expert Beginner". This leads to stagnation, and no interest to improve. What's worse it affects their coworkers.

I really recommend you to read The Expert Beginner. It's quick read (68 pages), and may help you not fall into this trap.

How to save money on Azure with WebJobs

ThisÂ blog is hosted on Azure. It is using WordPress, which stores its data inÂ MySQL database hosted by ClearDb.Â I blogged about the issues with WordPress database sizeÂ over a year ago. The issue is inserting transient entries into database that are growing its size and exceeding free 20MB ClearDB limit. As I mentioned in this blog post - you can use plugins that clearÂ database for you, or...you can use web jobs.Â Azure WebJobs is very neat way to perform custom tasks, such asÂ database maintenance, periodically.

I createdÂ a web job that is performing database maintenance for me. Everyday it removes 'transient' entries from wp_options tableÂ to keep my MySQL database under 20MB ClearDB limit.

One problemÂ was: how to do MySQL backup without mysqldump? As you know,Â there is a Virtual Machine underneath every Azure website. And this VM has MySQL, along with mysqldump installed:

Based on this articleÂ I created a small Console App calledÂ DbMaintenance that performs 3 mentioned tasks:

  1. Backup database
  2. Remove transient entries from wp_options table.
  3. Backup database

Two backups gives me more confidence that I have my database backed up correctly. Especially because I am performing them before and after the operation that potentially can broke things.

You can customize myÂ app by editing Initialize method. Current paths (for mysqldump and database backup directory) are set for Azure Website. AdditionallyÂ you have to create directory for backups (D:\home\db-backups). You can do it from the webÂ appÂ console available on the Azure Portal:

mkdir D:\home\db-backup

Once this is done, you need to zip DbMaintenance.exe and MySql.Data.dll file, and create a WebJob. On the Azure Portal go to your web appÂ -> Settings -> WebJobs, and add a new WebJob:

You can see the status in Settings -> WebJobs -> YOUR_JOB_NAME:

By clicking onÂ logs column, you can get details about web job:

And console output from each execution:

I configuredÂ my WebJob to run everyday. You can also run it on demand, or continuously.

You can find more about Azure WebJobs in this article.
